FRSKY_DNLINK1_ID.Description: Change the first extra downlink sensor id (SPort only)

FRSKY_DNLINK2_ID.Description: Change the second extra downlink sensor id (SPort only)

FRSKY_DNLINK_ID.Description: Change the default downlink sensor id (SPort only)

FRSKY_OPTIONS.Description: A bitmask to set some FRSky Telemetry specific options

FRSKY_UPLINK_ID.Description: Change the uplink sensor id (SPort only)

FS_EKF_THRESH.Description: Allows setting the maximum acceptable compass and velocity variance used to check navigation health in VTOL modes

FS_GCS_ENABL.Description: Enable ground control station telemetry failsafe. Failsafe will trigger after FS_LONG_TIMEOUT seconds of no MAVLink heartbeat messages. There are three possible enabled settings. Setting FS_GCS_ENABL to 1 means that GCS failsafe will be triggered when the aircraft has not received a MAVLink HEARTBEAT message. Setting FS_GCS_ENABL to 2 means that GCS failsafe will be triggered on either a loss of HEARTBEAT messages, or a RADIO_STATUS message from a MAVLink enabled 3DR radio indicating that the ground station is not receiving status updates from the aircraft, which is indicated by the RADIO_STATUS.remrssi field being zero (this may happen if you have a one way link due to asymmetric noise on the ground station and aircraft radios).Setting FS_GCS_ENABL to 3 means that GCS failsafe will be triggered by Heartbeat(like option one), but only in AUTO mode. WARNING: Enabling this option opens up the possibility of your plane going into failsafe mode and running the motor on the ground it it loses contact with your ground station. If this option is enabled on an electric plane then you should enable ARMING_REQUIRED.

FS_LONG_ACTN.Description: The action to take on a long (FS_LONG_TIMEOUT seconds) failsafe event. If the aircraft was in a stabilization or manual mode when failsafe started and a long failsafe occurs then it will change to RTL mode if FS_LONG_ACTN is 0 or 1, and will change to FBWA if FS_LONG_ACTN is set to 2. If the aircraft was in an auto mode (such as AUTO or GUIDED) when the failsafe started then it will continue in the auto mode if FS_LONG_ACTN is set to 0, will change to RTL mode if FS_LONG_ACTN is set to 1 and will change to FBWA mode if FS_LONG_ACTN is set to 2. If FS_LONG_ACTION is set to 3, the parachute will be deployed (make sure the chute is configured and enabled).

FS_LONG_TIMEOUT.Description: The time in seconds that a failsafe condition has to persist before a long failsafe event will occur. This defaults to 5 seconds.

FS_SHORT_ACTN.Description: The action to take on a short (FS_SHORT_TIMEOUT) failsafe event. A short failsafe event can be triggered either by loss of RC control (see THR_FS_VALUE) or by loss of GCS control (see FS_GCS_ENABL). If in CIRCLE or RTL mode this parameter is ignored. A short failsafe event in stabilization and manual modes will cause a change to CIRCLE mode if FS_SHORT_ACTN is 0 or 1, a change to FBWA mode with zero throttle if FS_SHORT_ACTN is 2, and a change to FBWB mode if FS_SHORT_ACTN is 4. In all other modes (AUTO, GUIDED and LOITER) a short failsafe event will cause no mode change if FS_SHORT_ACTN is set to 0, will cause a change to CIRCLE mode if set to 1, will change to FBWA mode with zero throttle if set to 2, or will change to FBWB if set to 4. Please see the documentation for FS_LONG_ACTN for the behaviour after FS_LONG_TIMEOUT seconds of failsafe.
FS_SHORT_ACTN.Values: 0:CIRCLE/no change(if already in AUTO|GUIDED|LOITER),1:CIRCLE,2:FBWA at zero throttle,3:Disable,4:FBWB

FS_SHORT_TIMEOUT.Description: The time in seconds that a failsafe condition has to persist before a short failsafe event will occur. This defaults to 1.5 seconds

FWD_BAT_IDX.Description: Which battery monitor should be used for doing compensation for the forward throttle

FWD_BAT_VOLT_MAX.Description: Forward throttle battery voltage compensation maximum voltage (voltage above this will have no additional scaling effect on thrust). Recommend 4.2 * cell count, 0 = Disabled. Recommend THR_MAX is set to no more than 100 x FWD_BAT_VOLT_MIN / FWD_BAT_VOLT_MAX, THR_MIN is set to no less than -100 x FWD_BAT_VOLT_MIN / FWD_BAT_VOLT_MAX and climb descent rate limits are set accordingly.
FWD_BAT_VOLT_MAX.DisplayName: Forward throttle battery voltage compensation maximum voltage

FWD_BAT_VOLT_MIN.Description: Forward throttle battery voltage compensation minimum voltage (voltage below this will have no additional scaling effect on thrust). Recommend 3.5 * cell count, 0 = Disabled. Recommend THR_MAX is set to no more than 100 x FWD_BAT_VOLT_MIN / FWD_BAT_VOLT_MAX, THR_MIN is set to no less than -100 x FWD_BAT_VOLT_MIN / FWD_BAT_VOLT_MAX and climb descent rate limits are set accordingly.
FWD_BAT_VOLT_MIN.DisplayName: Forward throttle battery voltage compensation minimum voltage

GCS_PID_MASK.Description: bitmask of PIDs to send MAVLink PID_TUNING messages for

GLIDE_SLOPE_MIN.Description: This controls the minimum altitude change for a waypoint before a glide slope will be used instead of an immediate altitude change. The default value is 15 meters, which helps to smooth out waypoint missions where small altitude changes happen near waypoints. If you don't want glide slopes to be used in missions then you can set this to zero, which will disable glide slope calculations. Otherwise you can set it to a minimum number of meters of altitude error to the destination waypoint before a glide slope will be used to change altitude.

GLIDE_SLOPE_THR.Description: This controls the height above the glide slope the plane may be before rebuilding a glide slope. This is useful for smoothing out an autotakeoff

GPS1_CAN_OVRIDE.Description: GPS Node id for first GPS. If 0 the gps will be automatically selected on a first-come-first-GPS basis.

GPS2_CAN_OVRIDE.Description: GPS Node id for second GPS. If 0 the gps will be automatically selected on a second-come-second-GPS basis.

GPS_AUTO_CONFIG.Description: Controls if the autopilot should automatically configure the GPS based on the parameters and default settings
GPS_AUTO_CONFIG.Values: 0:Disables automatic configuration,1:Enable automatic configuration for Serial GPSes only,2:Enable automatic configuration for DroneCAN as well

GPS_AUTO_SWITCH.Description: Automatic switchover to GPS reporting best lock, 1:UseBest selects the GPS with highest status, if both are equal the GPS with highest satellite count is used 4:Use primary if 3D fix or better, will revert to 'UseBest' behaviour if 3D fix is lost on primary
GPS_AUTO_SWITCH.Values: 0:Use primary,1:UseBest,2:Blend,4:Use primary if 3D fix or better

GPS_BLEND_MASK.Description: Determines which of the accuracy measures Horizontal position, Vertical Position and Speed are used to calculate the weighting on each GPS receiver when soft switching has been selected by setting GPS_AUTO_SWITCH to 2(Blend)

GPS_BLEND_TC.Description: Controls the slowest time constant applied to the calculation of GPS position and height offsets used to adjust different GPS receivers for steady state position differences.

GPS_CAN_NODEID1.Description: GPS Node id for first-discovered GPS.

GPS_CAN_NODEID2.Description: GPS Node id for second-discovered GPS.

GPS_COM_PORT.Description: The physical COM port on the connected device, currently only applies to SBF GPS

GPS_COM_PORT2.Description: The physical COM port on the connected device, currently only applies to SBF GPS

GPS_DELAY_MS.Description: Controls the amount of GPS measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

GPS_DELAY_MS2.Description: Controls the amount of GPS measurement delay that the autopilot compensates for. Set to zero to use the default delay for the detected GPS type.

GPS_DRV_OPTIONS.Bitmask: 0:Use UART2 for moving baseline on ublox,1:Use base station for GPS yaw on SBF,2:Use baudrate 115200,3:Use dedicated CAN port b/w GPSes for moving baseline,4:Use ellipsoid height instead of AMSL

GPS_GNSS_MODE.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the first GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

GPS_GNSS_MODE2.Description: Bitmask for what GNSS system to use on the second GPS (all unchecked or zero to leave GPS as configured)

GPS_INJECT_TO.Description: The GGS can send raw serial packets to inject data to multiple GPSes.
GPS_INJECT_TO.Values: 0:send to first GPS,1:send to 2nd GPS,127:send to all

GPS_MB1_OFS_X.Description: X position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive X is forward of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_MB1_OFS_Y.Description: Y position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Y is to the right of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_MB1_OFS_Z.Description: Z position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Z is down from the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_MB1_TYPE.Description: Controls the type of moving base used if using moving base.

GPS_MB2_OFS_X.Description: X position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive X is forward of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_MB2_OFS_Y.Description: Y position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Y is to the right of the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_MB2_OFS_Z.Description: Z position of the base (primary) GPS antenna in body frame from the position of the 2nd antenna. Positive Z is down from the 2nd antenna. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_MB2_TYPE.Description: Controls the type of moving base used if using moving base.

GPS_MIN_DGPS.Description: Sets the minimum type of differential GPS corrections required before allowing to switch into DGPS mode.
GPS_MIN_DGPS.DisplayName: Minimum Lock Type Accepted for DGPS

GPS_MIN_ELEV.Description: This sets the minimum elevation of satellites above the horizon for them to be used for navigation. Setting this to -100 leaves the minimum elevation set to the GPS modules default.

GPS_POS1_X.Description: X position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS1_Y.Description: Y position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS1_Z.Description: Z position of the first GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS2_X.Description: X position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS2_Y.Description: Y position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_POS2_Z.Description: Z position of the second GPS antenna in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use antenna phase centroid location if provided by the manufacturer.

GPS_PRIMARY.Description: This GPS will be used when GPS_AUTO_SWITCH is 0 and used preferentially with GPS_AUTO_SWITCH = 4.

GPS_RATE_MS.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz(default) is not allowed. Raising the rate above 5Hz usually provides little benefit and for some GPS (eg Ublox M9N) can severely impact performance.

GPS_RATE_MS2.Description: Controls how often the GPS should provide a position update. Lowering below 5Hz(default) is not allowed. Raising the rate above 5Hz usually provides little benefit and for some GPS (eg Ublox M9N) can severely impact performance.

GPS_RAW_DATA.Description: Handles logging raw data; on uBlox chips that support raw data this will log RXM messages into logger; on Septentrio this will log on the equipment's SD card and when set to 2, the autopilot will try to stop logging after disarming and restart after arming
GPS_RAW_DATA.Values: 0:Ignore,1:Always log,2:Stop logging when disarmed (SBF only),5:Only log every five samples (uBlox only)

GPS_SAVE_CFG.Description: Determines whether the configuration for this GPS should be written to non-volatile memory on the GPS. Currently working for UBlox 6 series and above.
GPS_SAVE_CFG.Values: 0:Do not save config,1:Save config,2:Save only when needed

GPS_SBAS_MODE.Description: This sets the SBAS (satellite based augmentation system) mode if available on this GPS. If set to 2 then the SBAS mode is not changed in the GPS. Otherwise the GPS will be reconfigured to enable/disable SBAS. Disabling SBAS may be worthwhile in some parts of the world where an SBAS signal is available but the baseline is too long to be useful.

GPS_SBP_LOGMASK.Description: Masked with the SBP msg_type field to determine whether SBR1/SBR2 data is logged

GRIP_AUTOCLOSE.Description: Time in seconds that gripper close the gripper after opening; 0 to disable

GRIP_GRAB.Description: PWM value in microseconds sent to Gripper to initiate grabbing the cargo

GRIP_NEUTRAL.Description: PWM value in microseconds sent to grabber when not grabbing or releasing

GRIP_REGRAB.Description: Time in seconds that EPM gripper will regrab the cargo to ensure grip has not weakened; 0 to disable

GRIP_RELEASE.Description: PWM value in microseconds sent to Gripper to release the cargo

GROUND_STEER_ALT.Description: Altitude at which to use the ground steering controller on the rudder. If non-zero then the STEER2SRV controller will be used to control the rudder for altitudes within this limit of the home altitude.

GROUND_STEER_DPS.Description: Ground steering rate in degrees per second for full rudder stick deflection

GUIDED_D.Description: D Gain which produces an output that is proportional to the rate of change of the error

GUIDED_FF.Description: FF Gain which produces an output value that is proportional to the demanded input

GUIDED_FLTD.DisplayName: PID Derivative term filter frequency in Hz

GUIDED_FLTE.DisplayName: PID Error filter frequency in Hz

GUIDED_FLTT.DisplayName: PID Target filter frequency in Hz

GUIDED_I.Description: I Gain which produces an output that is proportional to both the magnitude and the duration of the error

GUIDED_IMAX.Description: The maximum/minimum value that the I term can output

GUIDED_P.Description: P Gain which produces an output value that is proportional to the current error value

GUIDED_SMAX.Description: Sets an upper limit on the slew rate produced by the combined P and D gains. If the amplitude of the control action produced by the rate feedback exceeds this value, then the D+P gain is reduced to respect the limit. This limits the amplitude of high frequency oscillations caused by an excessive gain. The limit should be set to no more than 25% of the actuators maximum slew rate to allow for load effects. Note: The gain will not be reduced to less than 10% of the nominal value. A value of zero will disable this feature.

HOME_RESET_ALT.Description: When the aircraft is within this altitude of the home waypoint, while disarmed it will automatically update the home position. Set to 0 to continously reset it.

ICE_ENABLE.Description: This enables internal combustion engine control

ICE_IDLE_DB.Description: This configures the deadband that is tolerated before adjusting the idle setpoint

ICE_IDLE_PCT.Description: This is the minimum percentage throttle output while running, this includes being disarmed, but not safe

ICE_IDLE_RPM.Description: This configures the RPM that will be commanded by the idle governor. Set to -1 to disable

ICE_IDLE_SLEW.Description: This configures the slewrate used to adjust the idle setpoint in percentage points per second

ICE_OPTIONS.Description: Options for ICE control. The DisableIgnitionRCFailsafe option will cause the ignition to be set off on any R/C failsafe. If ThrottleWhileDisarmed is set then throttle control will be allowed while disarmed for planes when in MANUAL mode.

ICE_PWM_IGN_OFF.Description: This is the value sent to the ignition channel when off

ICE_PWM_IGN_ON.Description: This is the value sent to the ignition channel when on

ICE_PWM_STRT_OFF.Description: This is the value sent to the starter channel when off

ICE_PWM_STRT_ON.Description: This is the value sent to the starter channel when on

ICE_REDLINE_RPM.Description: Maximum RPM for the engine provided by the manufacturer. A value of 0 disables this feature. See ICE_OPTIONS to enable or disable the governor.
ICE_REDLINE_RPM.DisplayName: RPM of the redline limit for the engine

ICE_RPM_CHAN.Description: This is which of the RPM instances to use for detecting the RPM of the engine

ICE_RPM_THRESH.Description: This is the measured RPM above which the engine is considered to be running

ICE_STARTCHN_MIN.Description: This is a minimum PWM value for engine start channel for an engine stop to be commanded. Setting this value will avoid RC input glitches with low PWM values from causing an unwanted engine stop. A value of zero means any PWM below 1300 triggers an engine stop.
ICE_STARTCHN_MIN.DisplayName: Input channel for engine start minimum PWM

ICE_STARTER_TIME.Description: This is the number of seconds to run the starter when trying to start the engine

ICE_START_CHAN.Description: This is an RC input channel for requesting engine start. Engine will try to start when channel is at or above 1700. Engine will stop when channel is at or below 1300. Between 1301 and 1699 the engine will not change state unless a MAVLink command or mission item commands a state change, or the vehicle is disarmed. See ICE_STARTCHN_MIN parameter to change engine stop PWM value and/or to enable debouncing of the START_CH to avoid accidental engine kills due to noise on channel.

ICE_START_PCT.Description: This is the percentage throttle output for engine start

INITIAL_MODE.Description: This selects the mode to start in on boot. This is useful for when you want to start in AUTO mode on boot without a receiver.

INS4_ACCOFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS4_ACCOFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS4_ACCOFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS4_ACCSCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS4_ACCSCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS4_ACCSCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS4_ACC_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the accelerometer was calibrated at

INS4_ACC_ID.Description: Accelerometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS4_GYROFFS_X.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS4_GYROFFS_Y.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS4_GYROFFS_Z.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS4_GYR_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the gyroscope was calibrated at

INS4_GYR_ID.Description: Gyro sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS4_POS_X.Description: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS4_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS4_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS4_TCAL_ACC1_X.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC1_X.DisplayName: Accelerometer 1st order temperature coefficient X axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC1_Y.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC1_Y.DisplayName: Accelerometer 1st order temperature coefficient Y axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC1_Z.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC1_Z.DisplayName: Accelerometer 1st order temperature coefficient Z axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC2_X.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC2_X.DisplayName: Accelerometer 2nd order temperature coefficient X axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC2_Y.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC2_Y.DisplayName: Accelerometer 2nd order temperature coefficient Y axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC2_Z.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC2_Z.DisplayName: Accelerometer 2nd order temperature coefficient Z axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC3_X.Description: This is the 3rd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC3_X.DisplayName: Accelerometer 3rd order temperature coefficient X axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC3_Y.Description: This is the 3rd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC3_Y.DisplayName: Accelerometer 3rd order temperature coefficient Y axis

INS4_TCAL_ACC3_Z.Description: This is the 3rd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_ACC3_Z.DisplayName: Accelerometer 3rd order temperature coefficient Z axis

INS4_TCAL_ENABLE.Description: Enable the use of temperature calibration parameters for this IMU. For automatic learning set to 2 and also set the INS_TCALn_TMAX to the target temperature, then reboot

INS4_TCAL_GYR1_X.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR1_X.DisplayName: Gyroscope 1st order temperature coefficient X axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR1_Y.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR1_Y.DisplayName: Gyroscope 1st order temperature coefficient Y axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR1_Z.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR1_Z.DisplayName: Gyroscope 1st order temperature coefficient Z axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR2_X.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR2_X.DisplayName: Gyroscope 2nd order temperature coefficient X axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR2_Y.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR2_Y.DisplayName: Gyroscope 2nd order temperature coefficient Y axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR2_Z.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR2_Z.DisplayName: Gyroscope 2nd order temperature coefficient Z axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR3_X.Description: This is the 3rd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR3_X.DisplayName: Gyroscope 3rd order temperature coefficient X axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR3_Y.Description: This is the 3rd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR3_Y.DisplayName: Gyroscope 3rd order temperature coefficient Y axis

INS4_TCAL_GYR3_Z.Description: This is the 3rd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS4_TCAL_GYR3_Z.DisplayName: Gyroscope 3rd order temperature coefficient Z axis

INS4_TCAL_TMAX.Description: The maximum temperature that the calibration is valid for. This must be at least 10 degrees above TMIN for calibration

INS4_TCAL_TMIN.Description: The minimum temperature that the calibration is valid for

INS4_USE.Description: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
INS4_USE.DisplayName: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

INS5_ACCOFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS5_ACCOFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS5_ACCOFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS5_ACCSCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS5_ACCSCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS5_ACCSCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS5_ACC_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the accelerometer was calibrated at

INS5_ACC_ID.Description: Accelerometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS5_GYROFFS_X.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS5_GYROFFS_Y.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS5_GYROFFS_Z.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS5_GYR_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the gyroscope was calibrated at

INS5_GYR_ID.Description: Gyro sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS5_POS_X.Description: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS5_POS_Y.Description: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS5_POS_Z.Description: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS5_TCAL_ACC1_X.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS5_TCAL_ACC1_X.DisplayName: Accelerometer 1st order temperature coefficient X axis

INS5_TCAL_ACC1_Y.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS5_TCAL_ACC1_Y.DisplayName: Accelerometer 1st order temperature coefficient Y axis

INS5_TCAL_ACC1_Z.Description: This is the 1st order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS5_TCAL_ACC1_Z.DisplayName: Accelerometer 1st order temperature coefficient Z axis

INS5_TCAL_ACC2_X.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration
INS5_TCAL_ACC2_X.DisplayName: Accelerometer 2nd order temperature coefficient X axis

INS5_TCAL_ACC2_Y.Description: This is the 2nd order temperature coefficient from a temperature calibration

INS5_USE.DisplayName: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

INS_ACC1_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the 1st accelerometer was calibrated at

INS_ACC2OFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC2OFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC2OFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC2SCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC2SCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC2SCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC2_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the 2nd accelerometer was calibrated at

INS_ACC2_ID.Description: Accelerometer2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_ACC3OFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC3OFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC3OFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACC3SCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC3SCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC3SCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC3_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the 3rd accelerometer was calibrated at

INS_ACC3_ID.Description: Accelerometer3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_ACCEL_FILTER.Description: Filter cutoff frequency for accelerometers. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

INS_ACCOFFS_X.Description: Accelerometer offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACCOFFS_Y.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACCOFFS_Z.Description: Accelerometer offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

INS_ACCSCAL_X.Description: Accelerometer scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACCSCAL_Y.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACCSCAL_Z.Description: Accelerometer scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

INS_ACC_BODYFIX.Description: The body-fixed accelerometer to be used for trim calculation

INS_ACC_ID.Description: Accelerometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_ENABLE_MASK.Description: Bitmask of IMUs to enable. It can be used to prevent startup of specific detected IMUs

INS_FAST_SAMPLE.Description: Mask of IMUs to enable fast sampling on, if available

INS_GYR1_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the 1st gyroscope was calibrated at

INS_GYR2OFFS_X.Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR2OFFS_Y.Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR2OFFS_Z.Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR2_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the 2nd gyroscope was calibrated at

INS_GYR2_ID.Description: Gyro2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_GYR3OFFS_X.Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR3OFFS_Y.Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR3OFFS_Z.Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYR3_CALTEMP.Description: Temperature that the 3rd gyroscope was calibrated at

INS_GYR3_ID.Description: Gyro3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_GYROFFS_X.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYROFFS_Y.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYROFFS_Z.Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

INS_GYRO_FILTER.Description: Filter cutoff frequency for gyroscopes. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

INS_GYRO_RATE.Description: Gyro rate for IMUs with fast sampling enabled. The gyro rate is the sample rate at which the IMU filters operate and needs to be at least double the maximum filter frequency. If the sensor does not support the selected rate the next highest supported rate will be used. For IMUs which do not support fast sampling this setting is ignored and the default gyro rate of 1Khz is used.
INS_GYRO_RATE.DisplayName: Gyro rate for IMUs with Fast Sampling enabled

INS_GYR_CAL.Description: Conrols when automatic gyro calibration is performed

INS_GYR_ID.Description: Gyro sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

INS_HNTC2_ATT.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter attenuation in dB. Values greater than 40dB will typically produce a hard notch rather than a modest attenuation of motor noise.

INS_HNTC2_BW.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter bandwidth in Hz. This is typically set to half the base frequency. The ratio of base frequency to bandwidth determines the notch quality factor and is fixed across harmonics.

INS_HNTC2_FM_RAT.Description: The minimum ratio below the configured frequency to take throttle based notch filters when flying at a throttle level below the reference throttle. Note that lower frequency notch filters will have more phase lag. If you want throttle based notch filtering to be effective at a throttle up to 30% below the configured notch frequency then set this parameter to 0.7. The default of 1.0 means the notch will not go below the frequency in the FREQ parameter.

INS_HNTC2_FREQ.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter base center frequency in Hz. This is the center frequency for static notches, the center frequency for Throttle based notches at the reference thrust value, and the minimum limit of center frequency variation for all other notch types. This should always be set lower than half the backend gyro rate (which is typically 1Khz).

INS_HNTC2_HMNCS.Bitmask: 0:1st harmonic,1:2nd harmonic,2:3rd harmonic,3:4th hamronic,4:5th harmonic,5:6th harmonic,6:7th harmonic,7:8th harmonic
INS_HNTC2_HMNCS.Description: Bitmask of harmonic frequencies to apply Harmonic Notch Filter to. This option takes effect on the next reboot. A value of 0 disables this filter. The first harmonic refers to the base frequency.

INS_HNTC2_MODE.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode. Dynamic updates can be throttle, RPM sensor, ESC telemetry or dynamic FFT based. Throttle-based updates should only be used with multicopters.
INS_HNTC2_MODE.DisplayName: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode

INS_HNTC2_OPTS.Bitmask: 0:Double notch,1:Dynamic harmonic,2:Update at loop rate,3:EnableOnAllIMUs,4:Triple notch
INS_HNTC2_OPTS.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter options. Triple and double-notches can provide deeper attenuation across a wider bandwidth with reduced latency than single notches and are suitable for larger aircraft. Dynamic harmonics attaches a harmonic notch to each detected noise frequency instead of simply being multiples of the base frequency, in the case of FFT it will attach notches to each of three detected noise peaks, in the case of ESC it will attach notches to each of four motor RPM values. Loop rate update changes the notch center frequency at the scheduler loop rate rather than at the default of 200Hz. If both double and triple notches are specified only double notches will take effect.

INS_HNTC2_REF.Description: A reference value of zero disables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter and a positive value enables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter. For throttle-based scaling, this parameter is the reference value associated with the specified frequency to facilitate frequency scaling of the Harmonic Notch Filter. For RPM and ESC telemetry based tracking, this parameter is set to 1 to enable the Harmonic Notch Filter using the RPM sensor or ESC telemetry set to measure rotor speed. The sensor data is converted to Hz automatically for use in the Harmonic Notch Filter. This reference value may also be used to scale the sensor data, if required. For example, rpm sensor data is required to measure heli motor RPM. Therefore the reference value can be used to scale the RPM sensor to the rotor RPM.

INS_HNTCH_ATT.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter attenuation in dB. Values greater than 40dB will typically produce a hard notch rather than a modest attenuation of motor noise.

INS_HNTCH_BW.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter bandwidth in Hz. This is typically set to half the base frequency. The ratio of base frequency to bandwidth determines the notch quality factor and is fixed across harmonics.

INS_HNTCH_FM_RAT.Description: The minimum ratio below the configured frequency to take throttle based notch filters when flying at a throttle level below the reference throttle. Note that lower frequency notch filters will have more phase lag. If you want throttle based notch filtering to be effective at a throttle up to 30% below the configured notch frequency then set this parameter to 0.7. The default of 1.0 means the notch will not go below the frequency in the FREQ parameter.

INS_HNTCH_FREQ.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter base center frequency in Hz. This is the center frequency for static notches, the center frequency for Throttle based notches at the reference thrust value, and the minimum limit of center frequency variation for all other notch types. This should always be set lower than half the backend gyro rate (which is typically 1Khz).

INS_HNTCH_HMNCS.Bitmask: 0:1st harmonic,1:2nd harmonic,2:3rd harmonic,3:4th hamronic,4:5th harmonic,5:6th harmonic,6:7th harmonic,7:8th harmonic
INS_HNTCH_HMNCS.Description: Bitmask of harmonic frequencies to apply Harmonic Notch Filter to. This option takes effect on the next reboot. A value of 0 disables this filter. The first harmonic refers to the base frequency.

INS_HNTCH_MODE.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode. Dynamic updates can be throttle, RPM sensor, ESC telemetry or dynamic FFT based. Throttle-based updates should only be used with multicopters.
INS_HNTCH_MODE.DisplayName: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode

INS_HNTCH_OPTS.Bitmask: 0:Double notch,1:Dynamic harmonic,2:Update at loop rate,3:EnableOnAllIMUs,4:Triple notch
INS_HNTCH_OPTS.Description: Harmonic Notch Filter options. Triple and double-notches can provide deeper attenuation across a wider bandwidth with reduced latency than single notches and are suitable for larger aircraft. Dynamic harmonics attaches a harmonic notch to each detected noise frequency instead of simply being multiples of the base frequency, in the case of FFT it will attach notches to each of three detected noise peaks, in the case of ESC it will attach notches to each of four motor RPM values. Loop rate update changes the notch center frequency at the scheduler loop rate rather than at the default of 200Hz. If both double and triple notches are specified only double notches will take effect.

INS_HNTCH_REF.Description: A reference value of zero disables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter and a positive value enables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter. For throttle-based scaling, this parameter is the reference value associated with the specified frequency to facilitate frequency scaling of the Harmonic Notch Filter. For RPM and ESC telemetry based tracking, this parameter is set to 1 to enable the Harmonic Notch Filter using the RPM sensor or ESC telemetry set to measure rotor speed. The sensor data is converted to Hz automatically for use in the Harmonic Notch Filter. This reference value may also be used to scale the sensor data, if required. For example, rpm sensor data is required to measure heli motor RPM. Therefore the reference value can be used to scale the RPM sensor to the rotor RPM.

INS_LOG_BAT_CNT.Description: Number of samples to take when logging streams of IMU sensor readings. Will be rounded down to a multiple of 32. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

INS_LOG_BAT_LGCT.Description: Number of samples to push to count every INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN

INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN.Description: Interval between pushing samples to the AP_Logger log

INS_LOG_BAT_MASK.Description: Bitmap of which IMUs to log batch data for. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

INS_LOG_BAT_OPT.Bitmask: 0:Sensor-Rate Logging (sample at full sensor rate seen by AP), 1: Sample post-filtering, 2: Sample pre- and post-filter

INS_POS1_X.Description: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS1_Y.Description: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS1_Z.Description: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS2_X.Description: X position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS2_Y.Description: Y position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS2_Z.Description: Z position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS3_X.Description: X position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS3_Y.Description: Y position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_POS3_Z.Description: Z position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

INS_STILL_THRESH.Description: Threshold to tolerate vibration to determine if vehicle is motionless. This depends on the frame type and if there is a constant vibration due to motors before launch or after landing. Total motionless is about 0.05. Suggested values: Planes/rover use 0.1, multirotors use 1, tradHeli uses 5
INS_STILL_THRESH.DisplayName: Stillness threshold for detecting if we are moving
